snippet.textDisplay: For anyone who doesnt have alot of fabric...Pillow cases will work   and  shoe laces are about 52  inchs long   also can use the ties from a Hoody    Saw where metal closures covered in plastic from re seal able food items   can be used for the wire.  A DR  posted a video and said Hepa Filter vacuum bags were safe for filters...  his wife posted a video for her pattern , This Ones BETTER!! ..As alot of us cant get out there to buy materials!  just thought to mention these......  Im going to make a whole lot of these!!  Im a Senior with Vasculitis and have a few friends with Lupus and Cancer......  Ive got alot of New  Bed sheets here,  Pillow cases are perfect  too!..  I make rag rugs!  GREAT  pattern and video!!  THANKS FOR SHARING!! .. BEST ONE IVE FOUND !!.....  THANK YOU FOR YOUR SERVICE and Please STAY SAFE!!  Everyone!
snippet.textOriginal: For anyone who doesnt have alot of fabric...Pillow cases will work   and  shoe laces are about 52  inchs long   also can use the ties from a Hoody    Saw where metal closures covered in plastic from re seal able food items   can be used for the wire.  A DR  posted a video and said Hepa Filter vacuum bags were safe for filters...  his wife posted a video for her pattern , This Ones BETTER!! ..As alot of us cant get out there to buy materials!  just thought to mention these......  Im going to make a whole lot of these!!  Im a Senior with Vasculitis and have a few friends with Lupus and Cancer......  Ive got alot of New  Bed sheets here,  Pillow cases are perfect  too!..  I make rag rugs!  GREAT  pattern and video!!  THANKS FOR SHARING!! .. BEST ONE IVE FOUND !!.....  THANK YOU FOR YOUR SERVICE and Please STAY SAFE!!  Everyone!

snippet.textDisplay: Overall I like this design. But, I wouldn't want the opening to the filter pocket to be right in the middle over the mouth.  I would consider making the inside fabric two different size rectangles that still added up to the same overall amount of inside fabric (that would make the filter opening offset).
snippet.textOriginal: Overall I like this design. But, I wouldn't want the opening to the filter pocket to be right in the middle over the mouth.  I would consider making the inside fabric two different size rectangles that still added up to the same overall amount of inside fabric (that would make the filter opening offset).

snippet.textDisplay: At the microbial level, think of the holes in your mask to breathe being the size of a doorway.  The coronavirus is approximately 125 nanometers long, hence relative to the doorway, the size of a marble. That is why WHO and other epidemiologists know that wearing a mask when you yourself are not coughing, or you are not attending to another who is coughing, is totally absolutely USELESS.  Ooops, but it is useful for one thing: virtue signalling.
snippet.textOriginal: At the microbial level, think of the holes in your mask to breathe being the size of a doorway. snippet.textDisplay: Experienced sewer, also a nurse. I made a mask following the instructions and found it easy to make. That being said, the mask is bulky and fits way too far into the neck. It covers the mouth and nose but again, the mask was too bulky when drawn up and left large gaps on the sides. This may be fine for others, it is easy to put together!

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks for this pattern! I found this design after making a few masks using other tutorials and I definitely prefer this approach. I was fortunate to have quite a bit of elastic on hand, so I've used a smaller length of that (36") instead of the synthetic cord which I didn't have on hand. In addition, I had a bunch of plastic toggles, so used those for an adjustable fit on the top of the head.
snippet.textOriginal: Thanks for this pattern! I found this design after making a few masks using other tutorials and I definitely prefer this approach. I was fortunate to have quite a bit of elastic on hand, so I've used a smaller length of that (36") instead of the synthetic cord which I didn't have on hand. In addition, I had a bunch of plastic toggles, so used those for an adjustable fit on the top of the head.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for sharing this video, very helpful!!  To everyone making masks for health care providers Please try to use latex-free elastics or rubber bands if you are donating these masks to hospital workers.  Regular elastics are made of natural latex, which is a sap from the hevea tree.  About 17% of healthcare workers are allergic to latex because of the gloves they wear and their symptoms can worsen if their skin is in contact with latex.  It’s a cumulative allergy, like bee stings, so the symptoms can become severe overnight when you’re exposed to latex.  Once you develop this allergy it’s for life and there’s no treatment or cure.  It’s best to avoid wearing latex / NRL gloves too if you can.  The safe ones are NITRILE or VINYL gloves.  Stay safe 🙌
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you for sharing this video, very helpful!!  To everyone making masks for health care providers Please try to use latex-free elastics or rubber bands if you are donating these masks to hospital workers.  Regular elastics are made of natural latex, which is a sap from the hevea tree.  About 17% of healthcare workers are allergic to latex because of the gloves they wear and their symptoms can worsen if their skin is in contact with latex.  It’s a cumulative allergy, like bee stings, so the symptoms can become severe overnight when you’re exposed to latex.  Once you develop this allergy it’s for life and there’s no treatment or cure.  It’s best to avoid wearing latex / NRL gloves too if you can.  The safe ones are NITRILE or VINYL gloves.  Stay safe 🙌

snippet.textDisplay: Synthetic clothesline will melt.  Run those snipped ends through a candle flame to quickly fuse those loose thread ends together so they don't fray.  But not too long, because it will burn, melt, turn black, and drip melted "plastic" on your hands.
snippet.textOriginal: Synthetic clothesline will melt.  Run those snipped ends through a candle flame to quickly fuse those loose thread ends together so they don't fray.  But not too long, because it will burn, melt, turn black, and drip melted "plastic" on your hands.

snippet.textDisplay: Since many stores aren't open or supplies are short, here is another idea instead of clothesline just don't make it too thin but this method is great for a long string. https://www.craftpassion.com/recycle-tutorial-making-of-t-shirt-yarn/

snippet.textDisplay:
Okay, I wasted some filter material working on other masks, but this one is PERFECT! As an as-needed seamstress, I love how easy this was to create, and how adjustable and comfortable. I use Miele vacuum bags as my filter, but this can easily be removed as needed. And the whole thing is washable!

Where I was going to create a few masks for my family, I am now going to create as many as I can with what materials I have for anyone who needs one. Thank you so much!!
snippet.textOriginal:
Okay, I wasted some filter material working on other masks, but this one is PERFECT! As an as-needed seamstress, I love how easy this was to create, and how adjustable and comfortable. I use Miele vacuum bags as my filter, but this can easily be removed as needed. And the whole thing is washable! 

Where I was going to create a few masks for my family, I am now going to create as many as I can with what materials I have for anyone who needs one. Thank you so much!!

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you!! Made one for my husband last night, using paracord and coated gardening wire from the DollarTree for the nose. We did add a cord stopper to the top back so he wouldn’t have to tie it. Our area became a need to wear area, so made another 8 for extended family today! May try to make more for donating real soon (had already made another pattern before finding yours and need more fabric). BTW my 14, 11 and 6 year old were able to help sew them all!!!

snippet.textDisplay: Easy peasy...I've not sewn for years...did 3 masks (of a different style) which were disposed (they were sewn so badly that they had to be disposed!) Since I'm working more at home than I was at school, time is precious. I'm going to make a bunch of these for my family (for use when they visit the grocery store or drug store) and local small business owners who have to work to survive. Thank you for your service and this great video!

snippet.textDisplay: This pattern is so simple and has such a good tight fit around the face while it is still very comfortable. I'm so glad I saw this today or I'd be pleating and pleating and I didn't have the energy to do that. My friends and family have asked me to make masks for them and I got 17 done today 4/hr. as opposed to my 1 or 2/hr with the pleat method. Thanks for such a nice tutorial.

snippet.textDisplay: If you absolutely can't get wire, you can try using a strip of aluminum foil folded several times to make it firmer.  It can be sewn into place where the wire goes and molded to fit around your nose once you put the mask on. (edit: My suggestion are for those making this mask for personal use.  I have a compromised immune system and trying to find the best diy mask that really works).
snippet.textOriginal: If you absolutely can't get wire, you can try using a strip of aluminum foil folded several times to make it firmer.  It can be sewn into place where the wire goes and molded to fit around your nose once you put the mask on. (edit: My suggestion are for those making this mask for personal use.  I have a compromised immune system and trying to find the best diy mask that really works).

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a psych RN/NP student and a med surg RN. I needed a mask to cover my N95 since I return to work this week and people are selling them for $20 here. I made three for about $4. I think you have the best design thus far and it only took me about two hours to sew ONE by hand! Lol (I'm not a seamstress at all:) I'm grateful for your channel, and my mask looks and feels great! Stay safe, my fellow nursing sister!!
snippet.textOriginal: I'm a psych RN/NP student and a med surg RN. I needed a mask to cover my N95 since I return to work this week and people are selling them for $20 here. I made three for about $4. I think you have the best design thus far and it only took me about two hours to sew ONE by hand! snippet.textDisplay:
This type of mask is useless. It's a surgical style mask made of DOUBLED UP material that doesn't allow proper airflow, let alone if you decided to add a "filter" in the "filter pocket"... In many cases, this mask is actually more harmful because the airflow occurs around the edges of the mask, often times right by the eye sockets. You end up directing air flow over your sinuses and eyes... Which is a BAD THING.. No registered nurse, or medical professional, would 'prefer' this mask.



This is just a project for people who are bored.. Not for people who actually want to protect themselves from exposure.
snippet.textOriginal:
This type of mask is useless.  It's a surgical style mask made of DOUBLED UP material that doesn't allow proper airflow, let alone if you decided to add a "filter" in the "filter pocket"...  In many cases, this mask is actually more harmful because the airflow occurs around the edges of the mask, often times right by the eye sockets.  You end up directing air flow over your sinuses and eyes... Which is a BAD THING..  No registered nurse, or medical professional, would 'prefer' this mask.



This is just a project for people who are bored..  Not for people who actually want to protect themselves from exposure.

snippet.textDisplay: As a nurse, I’m just wondering if that opening is uncomfortable right in front of your nose/mouth. It’s also an unfortunate place to have the least layers of protection if it gapes open. Does this happen? I guess you could alter the opening to be higher as well.

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks for a great video and explanation.  I've looked at 1 dozen tutorials and am going with yours. I'm grateful you know to use clips and not pins.  I am an experienced sewer, and a retired registered nurse. Can't volunteer because I have underlying lung issues, and immuno-compromised.  I'm excited to make these masks for front-line people in my area.  I so appreciate you making this public...we are all in this together.  Stay safe and wash your hands....oh, and remind your viewers to wash their hand before sewing each mask!!! Thanks again!
snippet.textOriginal: Thanks for a great video and explanation.  I've looked at 1 dozen tutorials and am going with yours. I'm grateful you know to use clips and not pins. Stay safe and wash your hands....oh, and remind your viewers to wash their hand before sewing each mask!!! Thanks again!
